statement.text: Varicose veins are dilated, tortuous superficial veins >3mm in diameter resulting from venous valvular incompetence and venous hypertension, affecting 20-25% of women and 10-15% of men, most commonly involving the great and small saphenous systems. Treatment has shifted from surgical stripping to endovenous ablation techniques.
statement.formal: Varicose_Veins: Diameter > 3mm + Reflux > 0.5 seconds; Prevalence: 20-25% women, 10-15% men; Treatment: Endovenous_Ablation (first-line)

explanation.intuition: Varicose veins are like pipes that have stretched and lost their one-way check valves. Without functioning valves, blood that should only flow toward the heart sloshes backward with every heartbeat, making the pipes bulge even more. It's a vicious cycle of more dilation leading to more valve failure.
explanation.key_insight: The key to treating varicose veins is understanding that the visible varicosities are usually tributaries - the underlying problem is reflux in the axial vein (GSV or SSV). Treating only the visible varicosities without addressing the source of reflux leads to recurrence. Always map with duplex ultrasound before treatment.
explanation.technical_details: Varicose veins result from primary valve failure (degenerative, genetic, hormonal) or secondary valve destruction (post-thrombotic). The terminal valve at the SFJ is often the first to fail, allowing reflux that propagates distally. Valve failure leads to sustained ambulatory venous hypertension, which dilates veins further, causing more valve failure. CEAP C2 disease (varicose veins) has prevalence of 25-30% in Western populations. Treatment has evolved from stripping to endovenous thermal ablation (laser, RFA) with >95% occlusion rates and lower recurrence than surgery.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Varicose veins are purely cosmetic. Reality: Untreated varicose veins can progress to skin changes and ulceration (C4-C6).
Misconception: Visible varicosities are the problem. Reality: They are tributaries; the axial reflux (GSV/SSV) is the root cause.
Misconception: Surgery is the best treatment. Reality: Endovenous ablation is now first-line with better outcomes than stripping.

epidemiology.age_of_onset: Most common in 4th-5th decades, increases with age

vein_classification.great_saphenous: Most common - medial thigh and leg

pathophysiology.primary_incompetence: Degenerative valve changes, genetic predisposition, hormonal effects

reflux_patterns.axial: GSV, SSV, or accessory saphenous veins
reflux_patterns.segmental: Isolated tributary reflux without axial involvement

pathophysiology.progression: Reflux → venous hypertension → vein dilation → more valve failure

presentation: Heavy, aching legs worse with standing
Symptoms improve with elevation and walking
diagnosis: Duplex ultrasound (gold standard) - map reflux, exclude DVT
Reflux criteria: >0.5 seconds for superficial, >1 second for deep
Identify axial vs tributary vs perforator reflux

endovenous_ablation.thermal: Endovenous laser (EVLA), radiofrequency (RFA) - first-line for GSV/SSV

surgery.indications: Large aneurysmal segments, failed prior treatment
surgery.procedures: High ligation, stripping, phlebectomy (less common now)

ceap_classification.C0: No visible or palpable venous disease
ceap_classification.reference: See CVD-001 for detailed CEAP breakdown

definition.@value: Dilated, tortuous superficial veins greater than 3mm in diameter resulting from venous valvular incompetence and venous hypertension, most commonly affecting the great and small saphenous systems.

sources.title: SVS/AVF Clinical Practice Guidelines for Varicose Veins

learning_objectives: Define varicose veins and distinguish from other venous abnormalities
Describe the pathophysiology of varicose vein development
Outline diagnostic approach including duplex ultrasound findings
Compare modern treatment options for varicose veins
clinical_pearls: Always perform duplex before treatment to map reflux patterns and exclude DVT
Visible varicosities are tributaries - the axial vein (GSV/SSV) is the problem
Endovenous ablation has largely replaced surgical stripping as first-line treatment
Reflux >0.5 seconds is abnormal for superficial veins
Untreated varicose veins can progress to skin changes and ulceration
